body:
> As long as something works in npm, I just don't think it's worth the time to figure out what pnpm is doing differently.

Warnings and errors are good - they let us know when we accidentally break contracts in ways that would be difficult to investigate ourselves. And isn't that the whole point of Eslint? ðŸ™‚

Also keep in mind that something not crashing in your own npm install doesn't mean the application will work properly (even for other npm users!). It may / did / will lead to strange cases of dependencies being added / removed / updated as you shuffle seemingly unrelated dependencies.

If you ask me, libraries like Eslint should probably consider _not_ using npm as their package manager of choice (in their own repository, I mean), and prefer using a stricter package manager that checks your dependencies. If it works there you're pretty much guaranteed it'll work everywhere, when there's no guarantee the other way around.

-->

-->

#### What changes did you make? (Give an overview)

Added docs for setting up a `.npmrc` file for pnpm.

fixes #19421


#### Is there anything you'd like reviewers to focus on?

body:
> Also keep in mind that something not crashing in your own npm install doesn't mean the application will work properly (even for other npm users!). It may / did / will lead to strange cases of dependencies being added / removed / updated as you shuffle seemingly unrelated dependencies.

@arcanis In my understanding, it's not ESLint that doesn't work well with pnpm, it's external packages such as `eslint-plugin-format` that don't expect and aren't tested under the standards enforced by pnpm. ESLint is the third party in this scenario, and the best we can do is providing advice to our users on how to work around the problems they may encounter with those tools. If you have a better idea, please let us know.

> If you ask me, libraries like Eslint should probably consider _not_ using npm as their package manager of choice (in their own repository, I mean), and prefer using a stricter package manager that checks your dependencies. If it works there you're pretty much guaranteed it'll work everywhere, when there's no guarantee the other way around.

This wouldn't make a difference as long as the incompatibilities with pnpm arise with other packages.

issue.title: Bug: error TS2742 in eslint.config.mjs with `"composite": true` and pnpm

labels.name: accepting prs
labels.description: Go ahead, send a pull request that resolves this issue

labels.name: package: typescript-eslint
labels.description: Issues related to the typescript-eslint package

repository.name: typescript-eslint
repository.description: :sparkles: Monorepo for all the tooling which enables ESLint to support TypeScript

issue.body:
### Before You File a Bug Report Please Confirm You Have Done The Following...

- [x] I have tried restarting my IDE and the issue persists.
- [x] I have updated to the latest version of the packages.
- [x] I have [searched for related issues](https://github.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/issues?q=is%3Aissue+label%3Abug) and found none that matched my issue.
- [x] I have [read the FAQ](https://typescript-eslint.io/linting/troubleshooting) and my problem is not listed.

### Issue Description

In a project configured with `"composite": true` and installed with pnpm, TypeScript flags error TS2742 in this minimal `eslint.config.mjs`.

```js
// @ts-check
import tseslint from "typescript-eslint";
export default tseslint.config(tseslint.configs.recommended);
```

`eslint.config.mjs:3:1 - error TS2742: The inferred type of 'default' cannot be named without a reference to '.pnpm/@typescript-eslint+utils@8.25.0_eslint@9.21.0_typescript@5.7.3/node_modules/@typescript-eslint/utils/ts-eslint'. This is likely not portable. A type annotation is necessary.`

Full `tsconfig.json`:

```json
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "allowJs": true,
    "composite": true,
    "module": "nodenext",
    "noEmit": true,
    "strict": true
  }
}
```

The error is not shown without `"composite": true`, nor is it shown when using npm instead of pnpm.

Related:

- #10508
- #10513 (merged in v8.18.2)

### Reproduction Repository Link

https://gist.github.com/andersk/44d8dd0d3c2508f758bf51e5cbf12c2f

### Repro Steps

```console
$ git clone https://gist.github.com/andersk/44d8dd0d3c2508f758bf51e5cbf12c2f test
$ cd test
$ pnpm i
Packages: +116
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
Progress: resolved 116, reused 116, downloaded 0, added 116, done

dependencies:
+ eslint 9.21.0
+ typescript 5.7.3
+ typescript-eslint 8.25.0

Done in 1.9s using pnpm v10.5.1

$ pnpm exec tsc
eslint.config.mjs:3:1 - error TS2742: The inferred type of 'default' cannot be named without a reference to '.pnpm/@typescript-eslint+utils@8.25.0_eslint@9.21.0_typescript@5.7.3/node_modules/@typescript-eslint/utils/ts-eslint'. This is likely not portable. A type annotation is necessary.

3 export default tseslint.config(tseslint.configs.recommended);
  ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


Found 1 error in eslint.config.mjs:3
```

### Versions

| package                                | version |
| -------------------------------------- | ------- |
| `@typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin`     | `8.25.0` |
| `@typescript-eslint/parser`            | `8.25.0` |
| `@typescript-eslint/scope-manager`     | `8.25.0` |
| `@typescript-eslint/typescript-estree` | `8.25.0` |
| `@typescript-eslint/type-utils`        | `8.25.0` |
| `@typescript-eslint/utils`             | `8.25.0` |
| `TypeScript`                           | `5.7.3` |
| `ESLint`                               | `9.21.0` |
| `node`                                 | `22.14.0` |
